author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Priest Impersonator Targeted Texas Churches, Officials Say
description: A man calling himself Father Martin stole $500 from a Houston church and visited six Dallas parishes, officials said. The man has also been spotted in two other states and Ontario.
content: A man impersonating a priest who calls himself Father Martin stole $500 from a church in Houston and showed up at six other parishes in Dallas last month, prompting security warnings among dioceses in Texas, church officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Army Overturns Convictions of 110 Black Soldiers Charged in 1917 Riot
description: The Army acknowledged that the soldiers, 19 of whom were hanged, had been convicted in military trials that were tainted by racial discrimination.
content: On Dec. 11, 1917, Pfc. Thomas C. Hawkins and 12 other Black soldiers who had been convicted of mutiny and other crimes during a riot in Houston earlier that year were hanged. It was the single largest mass execution of American soldiers by the Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maya King
title: Tim Scott’s Campaign Collapse: Debate Flops, Mistrust and an AWOL Billionaire
description: Externally, Mr. Scott’s brand of relentless optimism never found traction. Internally, his campaign was plagued by missteps, and a huge sum expected from a key donor never materialized.
content: It was late October and Tim Scott’s campaign manager, Jennifer DeCasper, was trying to rally the troops on an all-staff call, announcing that they would soon relocate to Iowa in a last-ditch move to salvage his floundering presidential bid. She broke the news from the back seat of an Uber, according to four people familiar with the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Hollywood Actors to Start Voting This Week on a New Contract
description: The tentative agreement would end the longest movie and television strike in SAG-AFTRA’s 90-year history.
content: For the past several months, production in Hollywood has been at a near standstill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Boncompagni
title: I Sent My Doctor a Selfie. Intentionally.
description: Teledermatology companies are disrupting skin care, and a lot of consumers are OK with that.
content: Four years ago, while skimming her Instagram feed, Fawzia Khan happened upon an ad for Dear Brightly, an online platform that sells prescription retinoids, a derivative of vitamin A that’s used topically to fight acne and aging skin, and available through doctors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Wertheim
title: America Is Losing Control
description: President Biden shows he has not learned from past mistakes.
content: Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, President Biden has presented himself as a statesman humbled and enlightened by his own country’s missteps after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. “While you feel that rage,” he advised Israelis, “don’t be consumed by it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Biden Strengthens Ties With Indonesia Despite Tensions Over the War in Gaza
description: Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, visited the White House and appealed to President Biden to call for a cease-fire. Mr. Biden focused instead on their new strategic partnership.
content: President Biden and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia met at the White House on Monday to announce a new strategic partnership, but their differing views on the conflict in Gaza came into view when Mr. Joko asked for the United States to “do more” to stop the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Under Pressure, Britain’s Leader Tries Another Reset With a Swerve to Center
description: After more than a year as prime minister, Rishi Sunak, a Conservative, has failed to close a yawning gap in the polls. On Monday he did something new.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain fired one of his most senior and divisive ministers on Monday, in a reshuffle of his top team that unexpectedly brought a centrist predecessor, David Cameron, back into government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler and Michael J. de la Merced
title: What’s at Stake in the Biden-Xi Meeting
description: President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, are set to meet on Wednesday, as the two seek to maintain ties despite trade tensions.
content: Nine months after the Chinese spy balloon controversy sent relations between Washington and Beijing to a new low, President Biden and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, will meet this week in San Francisco for face-to-face talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Shirley Jo Finney, 74, Dies; Addressed the Black Experience Onstage
description: After an acting career that included playing the Olympic sprinter Wilma Rudolph in a TV movie, she became known as a director for her work at regional theaters.
content: Shirley Jo Finney, an actor who became a prolific and award-winning director of plays that dug deeply into the Black experience, died on Oct. 10 in Bellingham, Wash. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Crisis at Gaza’s Main Hospital, and More
description: Plus, Tim Scott suspends his campaign for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and a rise in reports of cognitive difficulties.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Who Is James Cleverly, Britain’s New Home Secretary?
description: Cleverly is generally seen as less ideological and more of a team player than his predecessor in the Home Office, Suella Braverman.
content: James Cleverly, who will move from his position leading the Foreign Office to become Britain’s home secretary, is generally seen as less ideological and more of a team player than his predecessor in the Home Office, Suella Braverman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Democratic Aides in Congress Break With Their Bosses on Israel-Hamas War
description: A wave of current and former staff members, mostly of a younger generation, are agitating for a cease-fire and speaking out against their bosses’ positions.
content: The carnations arrived by the wheelbarrow. Blood-red, pink, orange and yellow, more than 10,000 stems were laid on the steps at the base of the Capitol against a clear blue sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: Can’t Think, Can’t Remember: More Americans Say They’re in a Cognitive Fog
description: Adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s are driving the trend. Researchers point to long Covid as a major cause.
content: There are more Americans who say they have serious cognitive problems — with remembering, concentrating or making decisions — than at any time in the last 15 years, data from the Census Bureau shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: State Department employees send Blinken ‘dissent’ cables over Gaza policy.
description: The messages urge the Biden administration to press Israel for a cease-fire, according to U.S. officials. Two were said to have been sent in the first week of the war.
content: Dozens of State Department employees have signed internal memos to Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken expressing serious disagreement with the Biden administration’s approach to Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, according to U.S. officials, part of a surging tide of internal disagreement within the Biden administration over the Middle East crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: An ‘Unimaginable’ Death Toll Among Anchorage’s Homeless Residents
description: With hundreds living outdoors and temperatures plummeting, Alaska’s largest city is struggling to halt a rising death toll among homeless residents.
content: The arrival of frigid temperatures and heavy snow in recent days has contributed to a spate of deaths of homeless people in Anchorage, Alaska, adding to a toll that had already left political leaders scrambling for new solutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Indianapolis Museum Leader, Hired After Racism Outcry, Leaves Her Role
description: Colette Pierce Burnette was appointed last year by Newfields, whose campus includes the Indianapolis Museum of Art.
content: Colette Pierce Burnette, who was hired to lead the Newfields campus that includes the Indianapolis Museum of Art after a controversy about a racially insensitive job posting, has left the organization after 15 months on the job and shortly after the arrival of a new museum director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘BlackBerry’ and ‘Jay-Z and Gayle King: Brooklyn’s Own’
description: AMC airs its original program in three parts. And Gayle King interviews Jay-Z on CBS.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 13-19. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Fake Reviews Are Rampant Online. Can a Crackdown End Them?
description: A wave of regulation and industry action has placed the flourishing fake review business on notice. But experts say the problem may be insurmountable.
content: After Dr. Mark J. Mohrmann completed a successful orthopedic procedure in 2019, his patient turned to Yelp, the review website, to share his appreciation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: Leila de Lima, Critic of Duterte’s Drug War, Is Released on Bail
description: Though she was never convicted, Ms. de Lima was detained for six years after she fiercely opposed the Philippine former president’s brutal war on drugs.
content: The Philippines released on bail its most famous political prisoner, Leila de Lima, whose six-year detention served as a stark warning to those who dared to question former President Rodrigo Duterte’s brutal drug war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Crain
title: A Pandemic Novel That Never Says ‘Pandemic’
description: Michael Cunningham’s “Day” peeks into the lives of a family on one specific April date across three years as life changes because of Covid and other challenges.
content: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Change-Oriented Prime Minister Chooses a Link to a Troubled Past
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has presented himself as a change agent, chose a predecessor, David Cameron, as his foreign secretary. But Mr. Cameron comes with political baggage.
content: When David Cameron resigned as Britain’s prime minister after losing the Brexit vote in 2016, he offered members of Parliament a rueful valedictory: “I was the future once.” Few, perhaps including Mr. Cameron himself, expected to see him return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Secret Service Agent Protecting Naomi Biden Fires Gun During Car Break-In
description: Three people were seen breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington late Sunday.
content: A Secret Service agent guarding one of President Biden’s granddaughters fired at three people seen breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle in Washington late Sunday but did not appear to have hit them, according to a senior law enforcement official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Searching for a Home: Test Your Knowledge
description: Are you familiar with the essentials of a home search? Take our quiz.
content: For most Americans, buying a home is the most significant investment of their lives. And yet, many embark on a search without doing some homework first. In a housing market where inventory is tight and interest rates are high, the best way for buyers to get a leg up is to educate themselves on the many elements of a home search. These include how much you’ll need to pay your broker, what will be involved in the loan application process and understanding the different kinds of homes available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: John Bailey, Oscars President at a Time of Strife, Dies at 81
description: A respected cinematographer, he guided the motion picture academy at the height of the #MeToo movement and dealt with infighting around the Oscar ceremony.
content: John Bailey, an accomplished cinematographer who was president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences from 2017 to 2019, a tumultuous period when Harvey Weinstein was excommunicated from the group and complaints mounted about the Academy Awards ceremony, died on Friday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts and Maggie Haberman
title: Maryanne Trump Barry, Retired Judge and Donald Trump Sister, Dies at 86
description: A former appellate federal judge in New Jersey, she supported her brother but, as audio recordings revealed in 2019, she could be scathingly critical of him.
content: Maryanne Trump Barry, a former federal judge who was an older sister of Donald J. Trump and served as both his protector and critic throughout their lives, has died. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Because the Sides Are Really the Star
description: Brown-butter mashed potatoes, roasted squash with hot honey and a fresh take on green bean casserole might outshine the turkey.
content: Are you Team Turkey, or Team Sides? My Thanksgiving happy place is all about gathering as many of my favorite side dishes as I can and throwing a big, buttery veg-and-carb-fest. It’s permission to eat both honey-roasted sweet potatoes and brown-butter mashed potatoes at the same meal without even a tinge of guilt. Thanksgiving comes but once a year; I believe in making the most of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Chile, Known for Its Wines and Piscos, Turns to Gin
description: Distilleries are popping up across the country as Chileans use the versatile spirit to showcase their country’s unique botanicals.
content: Last Hope Distillery is one of the only real cocktail bars in Puerto Natales, a horseshoe of a city that wraps around a windy inlet in Chilean Patagonia. To enter, visitors buzz, speakeasy-style, then hang up their coats and settle in at the bar. A server sets a glass down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here Is a List of the New U.K. Cabinet so Far
description: David Cameron, a former British prime minister, is taking over as foreign secretary.
content: British government reshuffles generally take place over a period of hours, with the pace of appointments sometimes halting or accelerating as politicians accept or decline new positions. Here’s what has been announced officially so far on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: After Calling Foes ‘Vermin,’ Trump Campaign Warns Its Critics Will Be ‘Crushed’
description: The former president’s Veterans Day speech used language similar to the dehumanizing rhetoric wielded by dictators like Hitler and Mussolini.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign rejected criticism that he was echoing the language of fascist dictators with his vow to root out his political opponents like “vermin,” then doubled down: It said on Monday that the “sad, miserable existence” of those who made such comparisons would be “crushed” with Mr. Trump back in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats Signal Openness to Plan to Avert Shutdown as Republicans Balk
description: The House could take up the proposal as early as Tuesday. With growing opposition from House Republicans, it will need Democrats’ backing.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson’s proposal to avert a government shutdown at the end of the week ran into increasing opposition on Monday from hard-line Republicans. But with Democratic opposition softening, it appeared the plan could be headed toward bipartisan approval within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: The latest from the war in Gaza.
content: Patients including babies at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza are dying because of a lack of power, medical staff said amid conflicting accounts from Israel and health authorities in Gaza over why a badly needed fuel delivery for the besieged and crumbling facility had been held up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When a Seat in the Theater Means a Seat in the Salon
description: “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding” is a play where the Black women in the audience are the ones who feel most at home.
content: In a scene in Jocelyn Bioh’s “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,” a man rolls in a cart of items to sell to the clients and stylists at the titular salon. I recognized the character immediately and sat up, anticipating the joke. I wasn’t the only one: A small contingency of the audience at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater started snickering and laughing before he had even fully stepped onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘A Murder at the End of the World’ Review: P.I. Meets A.I.
description: The story of death at a mogul’s retreat (no, not “Glass Onion”) has a few interesting ideas about tech within a familiar mystery scenario.
content: An eccentric tech billionaire invites a slew of notables to a private retreat, where a detective must solve a mysterious death. If the premise of “A Murder at the End of the World” jumps out at you, it may be because you not so long ago encountered it as the premise of Rian Johnson’s “Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: America Needs a Serious Talk About How to Shrink Its Deficits
description: Interest rates are making U.S. debt a bigger burden. A bipartisan commission could find solutions.
content: You need to put politics aside to shrink government budget deficits — or that’s the conventional wisdom, anyway. Heidi Heitkamp disagrees. Heitkamp, who served one term in the U.S. Senate as a Democrat from the red state North Dakota, argues that it’s impossible to cut deficits and restrain the growth of the national debt without politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: As the Republican Field Narrows, Nikki Haley Makes a $10 Million Move
description: The former ambassador to the U.N. is reserving her first ads in Iowa and New Hampshire as she looks to outstrip Gov. Ron DeSantis in the race for second place.
content: Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign plans to reserve $10 million in television, radio and digital advertising in Iowa and New Hampshire starting in the first week of December — its first investment in advertising this cycle and a move meant to give the candidate a boost as the clock ticks for the field to make significant gains against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Victor Mather
title: N.Y. Area Amtrak Service Paused Over Problems With Garage Above Tracks
description: Service has been suspended for two days between New York City and Westchester because structural issues were found in a garage above the tracks in Manhattan.
content: Amtrak train service on the line between New York City and Albany remained disrupted for a second day on Monday after structural issues were discovered in a parking garage above the train tracks in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: New York Democrat Announces Early Departure From House, Citing G.O.P. Dysfunction
description: Representative Brian Higgins, Democrat of New York, said he would step down in February.
content: Representative Brian Higgins, Democrat of New York, said on Sunday that he would leave Congress in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Cracking the Green Bean Casserole Code
description: Eric Kim cooked 13 iterations of the midcentury Thanksgiving staple to create the ultimate recipe for today.
content: Dorcas Tarbell restocks her 97-year-old father’s fridge from a grocery list he gives her every week. One of the items that’s often on that list is a frozen TV dinner of green bean casserole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman and Hilary Swift
title: ‘A Monster’: Super Meth and Other Drugs Push Crisis Beyond Opioids
description: Millions of U.S. drug users now are addicted to several substances, not just opioids like fentanyl and heroin. The shift is making treatment far more difficult.
content: Dr. Nic Helmstetter crab-walked down a steep, rain-slicked trail into a grove of maple and cottonwood trees to his destination: a dozen tents in a clearing by the Kalamazoo River, surrounded by the detritus of lives perpetually on the move. Discarded red plastic cups. A wet sock flung over a bush. A carpet square. And scattered across the forest floor: orange vial caps and used syringes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: How Much Can Trees Fight Climate Change? Massively, but Not Alone, Study Finds.
description: The research, which comes with important caveats, was partly an effort to address the scientific uproar surrounding an earlier paper.
content: Restoring global forests where they occur naturally could potentially capture an additional 226 gigatons of planet-warming carbon, equivalent to about a third of the amount that humans have released since the beginning of the Industrial Era, according to a new study published on Monday in the journal Nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: An Atmospheric River Will Bring Rain and Snow to California This Week
description: It’s still too early to know just how much, though.
content: A first of many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: America’s Other Drug Problem
description: The crisis increasingly involves drugs besides opioids.
content: When political leaders talk about America’s current drug crisis, they are typically referring to opioids like painkillers, heroin and fentanyl. And when they have passed laws to deal with the problem in the past decade, those policies have centered on opioids. They have, for example, focused on boosting access to medications that treat only opioid addiction or reverse only opioid overdoses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. says that without fuel it can no longer distribute humanitarian aid.
description: The lack of fuel, used to operate the fork lifts that unload the goods and the trucks that deliver them, is imperiling the only lifeline for the 2.2 million people in the coastal enclave.
content: The United Nations said on Monday that its already dwindling reserve of fuel in the Gaza Strip would run out as soon as Tuesday, preventing the organization from receiving and distributing the desperately needed aid trickling in, and imperiling the only lifeline for the 2.2 million people in the coastal enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Where Is the Line Between Helping a Child Become More Resilient and Pushing Them Too Hard?
description: Has a parent ever challenged you to be more resilient? If so, were you grateful for the encouragement? Or did it go too far?
content: Has a parent, a teacher, a coach or some other caring adult ever pushed you to try something new? To persevere through a difficult situation? To do something that you thought you couldn’t do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Donald Trump Jr. Says Family Properties Show His Father’s Brilliance
description: In his second appearance in court, Donald J. Trump’s eldest son testified that the company’s assets were extremely valuable. A judge has found their values were inflated.
content: Donald J. Trump’s signature properties are at the heart of a sweeping civil fraud case accusing him of manipulating their values and his net worth. To hear the former president’s eldest son tell it, those properties prove something far rosier: the brilliance of the Trump family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Maybe This Is Why Donald Trump Is Afraid to Debate Nikki Haley
description: That exchange at last week’s debate about high heels wasn’t a throwaway moment.
content: If Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis have the best shot at taking on Donald Trump for the Republican presidential nomination, there was an especially telling moment at Wednesday’s debate that shows why Ms. Haley might be better suited to endure and overcome Mr. Trump’s lines of attacks than Mr. DeSantis would be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Turkey Potpie, Guinea Fowl and a Hybrid Turnip for the Thanksgiving Table
description: Aprons for a good cause, a roasting pan for the holiday bird and more food news.
content: Not enough Thanksgiving guests for a 12 to 16 pounder? There are other avian options to bronze in the oven and present with panache. There’s guinea fowl (above), a pasture-raised bird with luscious dark meat that’s not gamy, which is as easy to roast as a chicken. Season the interior with salt and pepper, tuck in a bunch of fresh herbs, rub the outside with butter, oil or duck fat, set it on a rack at 375 degrees and roast a large one, four pounds or so to serve six, for an hour and 20 minutes. You’ll only need about an hour for a 2- to 3-pounder serving two to four. Heritage Foods has 4- to 4.5-pound guinea hens raised by the Good Shepherd Poultry Ranch Network based in Kansas. D’Artagnan sells 2 to 3 pound hens from California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Two Astronauts Lost a Tool Bag in Space. It’s Not Alone.
description: The astronauts lost track of the bag while performing maintenance outside the International Space Station this month. Now it’s floating in space.
content: Lost: One tool bag. Last seen this month floating through space near the International Space Station. If found, please return to NASA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Robins and Stephen Castle
title: Cameron’s Return Relies on a Procedure That’s Unusual, but Not Unprecedented
description: Ministers in Britain have to hold a seat in Parliament, but the government can create a place in the House of Lords to satisfy that requirement.
content: One distinctive feature of Britain’s political system is that ministers are required to hold a seat in Parliament to propose legislation and be held to account by fellow lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Spanberger Announces Run for Governor in Virginia, Leaving House Seat in Play
description: The centrist Democrat helped deliver her party the House majority in 2018, and her decision to seek higher office could make it more difficult for Democrats to reclaim control in 2024.
content: Representative Abigail Spanberger, a prominent Virginia Democrat who was repeatedly able to win in a conservative-leaning district, announced on Monday that she would run for governor in 2025, leaving open a competitive seat that could be crucial to her party’s efforts to win back control of the House next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Edgar Sandoval and Robert Gebeloff
title: What It Means to Be a Texan Is Changing in Surprising Ways
description: White people make up a declining minority in Texas, even among those born in the state. And all those people moving in? They’re as likely to be Black, Hispanic or Asian.
content: Silhouetted against the predawn light of the West Texas sky, a group of oil field workers got ready for the tough job ahead on a September day — cleaning up a spill on a rig outside of Odessa — speaking a mix of English and Spanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: MasterVoices Puts on a Starry Show With a Shoestring Budget
description: This essential organization gives fresh, entertaining life to music theater curiosities. What if it had more money?
content: There’s a lot of Stephen Sondheim in New York at the moment: the premiere staging of his last musical, “Here We Are,” and star-studded revivals of “Merrily We Roll Along” and “Sweeney Todd” on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Polluting Industries Say the Cost of Cleaner Air Is Too High
description: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.
content: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is about to announce new regulations governing soot — the particles that trucks, farms, factories, wildfires, power plants and dusty roads generate. By law, the agency isn’t supposed to consider the impact on polluting industries. In practice, it does — and those industries are warning of dire economic consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Federal Prosecutors Object to Trump Request for Broadcast of Election Trial
description: The office of the special counsel said that televising the proceeding would create a “carnival atmosphere” and allow the former president to divert attention from the charges he faces.
content: Federal prosecutors on Monday accused former President Donald J. Trump of trying to turn his trial on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election into “a media event” with a “carnival atmosphere” by backing calls to have it broadcast live on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: What to Know About the Flu Virus
description: What’s the difference between influenza A and influenza B, and does it matter which you catch?
content: Each fall, the flu emerges as a formidable force, spreading through the droplets produced when people cough, sneeze or talk, and sometimes hitching a ride to our noses by way of the infected surfaces that we touch. Influenza viruses cause tens of millions of illnesses and thousands of deaths in the United States each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Will the Tie Ever Make a Comeback?
description: A reader wonders whether men’s neckties are a relic of the past.
content: As my colleague Guy Trebay, our men’s wear critic, said when I asked him about ties, “It never pays to sound the death knell in fashion since even the most seemingly defunct articles of clothing have a way of rising from the dead, and this is particularly so in men’s wear, where the repertoire is limited and largely based on centuries-old customs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Kevin Wynn, Choreographer of Complex Movement, Dies at 67
description: He became known for his “layered movement dialogue” and was an uncommonly dedicated teacher who mentored students over decades.
content: Kevin Wynn, a choreographer of complex maelstroms that moved at lightning speed and an uncommonly dedicated teacher who influenced generations of dancers, died on Oct. 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A Victorian cottage in Little River, a three-bedroom bungalow with a guesthouse in Los Angeles and a renovated 1913 home in Berkeley.
content: This house is perched above Van Damme State Beach, within walking distance of several popular trails and Spring Ranch Nature Preserve. It is less than five minutes from Little River Inn Golf and Tennis Club, which has a nine-hole golf course where players have spotted great horned owls, ospreys and bobcats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: An ‘Unsettling’ Drop in Life Expectancy for Men
description: The life expectancy gap between men and women reached its widest in nearly three decades, driven by more men dying of Covid and drug overdoses.
content: The gap in life expectancy between men and women in the United States grew to its widest in nearly 30 years, driven mainly by more men dying of Covid and drug overdoses, according to a new study in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Regents Exams May Become Optional for High School Graduation in New York
description: The tests had once been seen as a hallmark of academic rigor, but high-stakes graduation tests have fallen out of favor nationally.
content: New York could soon stop requiring many high school students to take Regents exams to earn a diploma, a major step in a sweeping overhaul of the state’s graduation system as it joins a national movement to rethink high-stakes exit exams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil Plans to Produce Lithium in Arkansas
description: The move is the oil giant’s first foray in the production of a metal vital for electric vehicle batteries.
content: Exxon Mobil said on Monday that it planned to set up a facility in Arkansas to produce lithium, a critical raw material for electric vehicles, which pose one of the biggest challenges to the company’s oil business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: A Look at Suella Braverman’s Turbulent Time as Home Secretary.
description: Ms. Braverman, who is no stranger to controversy, has now been fired from the post of home secretary twice.
content: Suella Braverman has embraced controversy in her time as a senior member of the Conservative government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Splinter Is Coming for These ‘Game of Thrones’ Trees
description: Six of the Dark Hedges beech trees, a tourist destination in Northern Ireland for fans of the HBO fantasy series, will be cut down because they are in poor condition, officials said.
content: Six trees with long branches that twist up to the sky that were made famous by the series “Game of Thrones” will be cut down in the coming weeks, officials in Northern Ireland said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: With Diana’s Death, ‘The Crown’ Enters Its Most Evocative Era
description: The final season of Netflix’s royal drama opens in 1997, on the cusp of one of the most analyzed periods in recent British history.
content: The images are joltingly familiar, even after all these years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Behind Public Assurances, Xi Jinping Has Spread Grim Views on U.S.
description: Speeches by the Chinese leader show how he was bracing for an intensifying rivalry with the United States from early in his rule.
content: When President Xi Jinping of China made his first state visit to the United States in 2015, he wrapped his demands for respect in reassurances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Looking to a Biden-Xi Meeting
description: Plus how much can trees help fight climate change.
content: President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, are set to meet tomorrow as the two seek to maintain ties and as business leaders watch for a thaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld, Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: What We Know About the Criminal Investigation Into Eric Adams’s Campaign
description: Federal authorities are examining whether the mayor’s 2021 campaign accepted illegal donations, including from the Turkish government.
content: After federal authorities raided the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s chief fund-raiser on Nov. 2, a broad criminal inquiry into the fund-raising practices of Mr. Adams’s 2021 campaign spilled into public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Attacks Intensify on Russian Forces in Occupied Regions of Ukraine
description: In the latest strike, Kyiv said three Russian officers were killed in a bombing in the southern city of Melitopol.
content: Ukrainian partisans killed three Russian officers in a bomb attack over the weekend, military authorities said, in a sign that Kyiv is stepping up its harassment of Moscow’s forces in the absence of decisive territorial progress on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su and Adam Westbrook
title: The Two-State Platitude
description: Once a hope for the future of Israel and the Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
content: In the decades-long effort to resolve the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, it has seemed to many like the least flawed among many imperfect ideas: the two-state solution. It would create an independent Palestinian state, made up of Gaza and the West Bank, that would exist alongside Israel. The goal has become official policy of most governments around the world and has been the basis for peace talks for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Adam Goldman and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: At Tourist Hotels, Israeli Evacuees Plan for Long Stays to Escape Border Attacks
description: More than 125,000 Israeli evacuees have been resettled from their communities along the dangerous borders with Lebanon and Gaza in the largest internal displacement in the country’s history.
content: A joyful clamor echoed in the ballroom of the Golden Crown Hotel. Kindergarten was in full swing for 30 children from Arab al-Aramshe, a village next to Israel’s border with Lebanon. Only this class was meeting 44 miles south, in Nazareth, where nearly 800 of the village’s residents have been living since mid-October, when they were evacuated because of the risk of attacks by the militant group Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Rachelle Bonja, Jessica Cheung, Lisa Chow, Liz O. Baylen, Ben Calhoun, Rowan Niemisto, Pat McCusker, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Doctors of Gaza
description: Doctors working inside the Gaza Strip tell their stories of survival.
content: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of injuries and death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Gospel Grammy Nominee Is Nearly Kicked Off Flight for Singing
description: In a widely shared video, a Delta flight attendant told the gospel singer Bobbi Storm that she would be removed if she would not listen to his instructions to be quiet.
content: A gospel singer was threatened with being removed from a Delta Air Lines flight after she refused to stop singing on the plane because, she said, she was “doing what the Lord” told her to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Under Pressure, Columbia Pledges $100 Million to Patients Doctor Abused
description: The institution said it “failed these survivors” in a letter on Monday apologizing for its role in the decades-long abuse by the gynecologist, Robert Hadden.
content: Nearly four months after a former Columbia University gynecologist was sentenced to 20 years in prison for abusing patients, the university on Monday apologized to victims and announced a “multipronged” response plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Rashida Tlaib, Censured by the House, Is Praised and Condemned at Home
description: The Democratic congresswoman from the Detroit area and the only Palestinian American in the House faces a complicated landscape in her district.
content: For more than a month, the suburbs of Detroit have played host to vigils where victims of the war between Israel and Hamas are commemorated with prayers, candles and tearful speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Russell Brand’s Alternate Reality
description: The British entertainer built an army of fans with his conspiracy-minded podcast. Now, amid sex-assault claims against him, they’ve become his whole world.
content: On Sept. 12, four days before he was expected at the Troubadour Wembley Park Theater for another sold-out show, Russell Brand asked his fans for a favor. “I’ve always struggled with authority and being told what to do,” he wrote to ticketholders, attaching a questionnaire for a planned bit with his audience. “Even when it comes to something small like being offered a seat by a doctor, I’ll purposefully refuse rather than comply. Tell me about your relationship with authority — whether you tend to yield to authority or fight it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘1989 (Taylor’s Version)’ Repeats at No. 1
description: Jung Kook of BTS’s solo album “Golden” debuts at No. 2 in another dominant week on the charts for Taylor Swift.
content: Taylor Swift holds the top of the Billboard 200 album chart with her latest remake, while Jung Kook of BTS opens at No. 2 and a posthumous release by Jimmy Buffett lands in the Top 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: CBS Says New Scripted Shows Will Return in February
description: The announcement is the first from a network about its plans since a tentative agreement was reached last week to end Hollywood’s strikes.
content: The lights are turning on again in Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Nepal Is Banning TikTok Over Hate Content, Officials Say
description: The small Himalayan nation’s cabinet of ministers said the Chinese-owned app had neglected its repeated requests to curb content that affected “social harmony.”
content: The government in Nepal said on Monday that it was banning the popular social media app TikTok, saying the platform’s refusal to curb hate content was affecting “social harmony.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Lady Bird Diaries’ Review: A 1960s First Lady Speaks
description: Lady Bird Johnson proves an engrossing narrator to her own story and that of a roiling nation.
content: “The Lady Bird Diaries” opens with images of a drizzly November day in Fort Worth, and the voice of Claudia Alta Johnson. Lady Bird Johnson — a nickname she acquired as child growing up in Texas — is recounting the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Hiba Yazbek
title: Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital Is ‘No Longer Functioning,’ W.H.O. Says
description: The agency warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for those trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.
content: Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital is no longer functioning, according to the World Health Organization, which warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for hundreds of patients and displaced people trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Tim Scott Suspends ’24 Campaign, as His Sunny Message Failed to Resonate
description: He entered the Republican presidential race as a rising star with substantial financial resources, but struggled to break out of the pack of Trump challengers.
content: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, who tried carving out a space in the Republican presidential field with a hopeful message built on his life story — the son of a single mother, he rose from poverty to become the only Black Republican in the Senate — announced on Sunday that he was suspending his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: This Photograph Demands an Answer
description: The news media doesn’t often publish graphic images of dead children. But this photograph must be seen.
content: If you don’t look too closely you might think the photograph is a dimly lit snapshot from a slumber party or a family camping trip. Six small children lie in a row, their heads poking out from the white sheet that is casually lying across their little chests. None appear to be older than 10, though it is hard to say for sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: exhortation
description: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word exhortation has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 20 in “One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer” by Scott Miller:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek, Ameera Harouda and Thomas Fuller
title: Death and Despair at Gaza Hospital as Fighting Reaches Its Doors
description: “I’m watching patients die in front of my eyes,” one doctor at a besieged hospital said, “and I can’t provide them the slightest bit of help.” Israel said its forces were targeting Hamas fighters.
content: With Israel’s ground war in the Gaza Strip in its third week, Israeli military vehicles on Monday arrived at the gates of a besieged hospital complex where fuel, medicine and food are running out. Inside the hospital, the nursing staff were moving 36 premature babies to the only department that still had oxygen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Opinion Today: When to Show War’s Horrors
description: On the difficult decision not to show the photograph at the center of a column published today.
content: Since the first use of photography to document battle in the Crimean War, there have been questions about the ethics of photojournalism in covering conflict and about how to regard the suffering of others depicted in that work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: North American Birds Will No Longer Be Named for Racists — or Anybody Else
description: Ornithologists and amateur birders alike have long wrestled with the historical nature of bird names bestowed by early collectors.
content: On Nov. 1, the American Ornithological Society announced that it would be renaming all the birds under its purview that are currently named for human beings. The birds’ new names will reflect the species’ appearance or habitat — some trait associated with the actual bird, in other words, and not with the colonial explorer who first identified it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: In Politics, There Are Worse Things Than Wishful Thinking
description: Does Nikki Haley’s rise suggest there might be life left in the Republican primary?
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, my attention these past few weeks has been devoted almost entirely to outrages and tragedies in the Middle East. But I couldn’t help smiling for a second when Nikki Haley called Vivek Ramaswamy “scum” at last week’s G.O.P. debate, after he raised the subject of her daughter’s use of TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Case on Outdoor Exercise for Prisoner in Solitary
description: The court’s three liberal justices dissented, saying that the prisoner, Michael Johnson, should be able to challenge prolonged denial of fresh air.
content: Over a forceful dissent from its three liberal members, the Supreme Court on Monday turned down an appeal from a prisoner in Illinois held in solitary confinement who said that prolonged denial of outdoor exercise was cruel and unusual punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: She’s Less Than Charming to Everglades Pythons
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 13, 2023.
content: “I had a family that went hunting with me instead of going to Disney World.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How Hoboken Got Smart About Climate Change
description: The New Jersey city has been more forward-thinking than New York in preparing for big storms.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the contrasts between two flood-prone cities on the Hudson River — New York and Hoboken, N.J. — in an era when climate change is bringing us more intense storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Adopts Ethics Code After Reports of Undisclosed Gifts and Travel
description: The code does not specify how the rules would be enforced or by whom.
content: The Supreme Court issued an ethics code on Monday after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the justices to adopt one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Why Does This Bride Look So Mad?
description: An 1866 painting by Auguste Toulmouche is being repurposed online as a conduit for women’s anger.
content: How long could you maintain your most withering glare? A minute? An hour?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: Hamas has held some Israeli hostages since long before Oct. 7.
description: Two Israeli citizens taken nearly a decade ago are believed to still be alive. Families are also fighting for the return of the remains of two soldiers killed in 2014.
content: The plight of families desperately seeking the return of their loved ones abducted from Israel on Oct. 7 is painfully familiar to Aviram Shaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israeli Forces Reached Gaza’s Main Hospital
description: Also, the Supreme Court adopts an ethics code. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israeli forces advanced today to the gates of Gaza’s largest hospital, where doctors describe a dire situation: Fuel, medicine and food are running out for hundreds of patients and thousands of others sheltering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Chevron Restarts Gas Production on Platform Near Gaza Strip
description: The energy giant had halted operations at the offshore facility on request from Israel’s government shortly after the attacks by Hamas militants last month.
content: Chevron said Monday that it had resumed production of natural gas from a platform in Israeli waters on instructions from the government. Israel’s Ministry of Energy had ordered the U.S. energy giant to halt production at the Tamar platform, shortly after the Oct. 7 raids by militants from Hamas in Israel and the start of Israel’s bombardment of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Speech and Antisemitism on Campus
description: Responses to articles about the tensions on college campuses. Also: Joe Manchin’s possible candidacy, and Jill Stein’s definite one; private art collections.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman and Lanna Apisukh
title: Hysteria or Healing? Examining the Power of the Shaking Body
description: The artist Liz Magic Laser considers quaking as both a symptom and a cure for psychological distress in “Convulsive States” at Pioneer Works.
content: As the choreographer and dancer Wendy Osserman, 81, began to contort her body at a recent performance in Queens, her hands shook. Her fingers flapped back and forth. She threw one arm away from the other — tossing and releasing, flailing and returning — and hopped into one-leg kicks before sticking her tongue out and coiling it into a tunnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Ma
title: Behind This Novel’s Cheery Facade Lies a Powerful Story of Immigration
description: In “Happy,” by Celina Baljeet Basra, a Punjabi farmer with big dreams finds more challenges than opportunity after he emigrates to Europe.
content: A friend recently told me he’d read an article in this paper describing the money to be made supplying migrants in their journey from South America to the United States. “Made me realize I don’t have any real understanding of the immigration situation,” my friend said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ankush Khardori
title: Financial Fraudsters Have Escaped Justice for Far Too Long
description: The Justice Department has been losing ground in the fight against financial fraud for years.
content: From a prosecutorial perspective, the Justice Department’s aggressive pursuit of Sam Bankman-Fried for financial fraud has been brutally efficient. His conviction came a year to the day after the public learned that there could be serious problems with the finances at his cryptocurrency exchange FTX, and it generated a wave of public interest and positive press for the department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Fighting to Govern Myanmar, From a Teeny Office in Washington
description: The National Unity Government of Myanmar, formed as an alternative to the junta that orchestrated a 2021 coup, has to battle global apathy and ignorance as it struggles for recognition.
content: Three blocks from the White House, at the end of a fluorescent-lit hallway on the sixth floor of a co-working space for “business nomads, freelancers and energetic entrepreneurs,” sits the American headquarters of the National Unity Government of Myanmar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden’s Pacific Trade Pact Suffers Setback After Criticism From Congress
description: The administration will no longer try to announce the completion of the trade terms this week, after prominent Democrats objected to some provisions.
content: The Biden administration has pulled back on plans to announce the conclusion of substantial portions of a new Asian-Pacific trade pact at an international meeting in San Francisco this week, after several top Democratic lawmakers threatened to oppose the deal, people familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Start-Ups With Laser Beams: The Companies Trying to Ignite Fusion Energy
description: Companies are looking to commercialize advances made by federally supported research labs in the quest for boundless energy.
content: Take a smidgen of hydrogen, then blast it with lasers to set off a small thermonuclear explosion. Do it right, and maybe you can solve the world’s energy needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Michael Gonchar
title: How Much Do You Know About Liberia?
description: Can you find Liberia on a map? What else do you know about this West African nation with 5.5 million people?
content: Can you find Liberia on a map? What else do you know about this West African nation with 5.5 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Supreme Court’s Ethics Rules
description: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it had issued an ethics code for the justices after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the court to adopt one. Here are the ethics rules.
content: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it had issued an ethics code for the justices after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the court to adopt one. Here are the ethics rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Fictional Places in Popular Novels?
description: Try this short quiz to see if you can identify the imaginary locations created by certain authors for their books.
content: Try this short quiz to see if you can identify the imaginary locations created by certain authors for their books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Por Marco Hernandez and Josh Holder
title: Los túneles de Gaza
description: Bajo la Franja de Gaza se extiende un laberinto de túneles que permite a los combatientes de Hamás pasar desapercibidos y contrabandear armas y mercancías.
content: Bajo la Franja de Gaza se extiende un laberinto de túneles que permite a los combatientes de Hamás pasar desapercibidos y contrabandear armas y mercancías.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Claire Hogan
title: The Signs Were All There. Why Did No One Stop the Maine Shooter?
description: The shooter who killed 18 people with an assault-style rifle in Lewiston, Maine, displayed a textbook set of warning signs. His family, his superiors in the military and the local police knew all of this. Yet no one stopped him.
content: The shooter who killed 18 people with an assault-style rifle in Lewiston, Maine, displayed a textbook set of warning signs. His family, his superiors in the military and the local police knew all of this. Yet no one stopped him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Rebecca Suner and Gabriel Blanco
title: Migrants Search for Beds as New York Quietly Stops Offering Them to All
description: New York City is legally obligated to provide a bed for every homeless person who asks for one, under a decades-old court settlement. But 18 months into a migrant crisis that shows no signs of abating, it has walked away from its obligation, at least for some.
content: New York City is legally obligated to provide a bed for every homeless person who asks for one, under a decades-old court settlement. But 18 months into a migrant crisis that shows no signs of abating, it has walked away from its obligation, at least for some.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps, Matthew Callahan, Rebecca Suner and Ruru Kuo
title: How U.S. Troops Were Harmed By Firing Their Own Guns
description: A secret U.S. offensive in 2016 and 2017 used an unusual strategy to fight the Islamic State: Put a minimal number of American troops on the ground and have them pound the enemy with artillery fire. What no one foresaw was the toll it would take on the troops who did the firing.
content: A secret U.S. offensive in 2016 and 2017 used an unusual strategy to fight the Islamic State: Put a minimal number of American troops on the ground and have them pound the enemy with artillery fire. What no one foresaw was the toll it would take on the troops who did the firing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley, Claire Hogan and Emily Rhyne
title: Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.
description: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam. In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market.
content: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam. In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron, Claire Hogan, Ruru Kuo and Rebecca Suner
title: How to Discuss Pain With Your Doctor
description: If you feel as though your pain is being ignored before, during or after a procedure, what do you do? Here are some tips on ways to advocate for yourself when speaking with a doctor.
content: If you feel as though your pain is being ignored before, during or after a procedure, what do you do? Here are some tips on ways to advocate for yourself when speaking with a doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Karen Hanley, Dave Horn and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: This County Has Predicted the President Since 1980
description: Voters in one county in Washington State have picked the winner in every presidential election from Reagan to Biden. What do they think now, a year from Election Day?
content: Voters in one county in Washington State have picked the winner in every presidential election from Reagan to Biden. What do they think now, a year from Election Day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Zhang and Claire Hogan
title: Trump Leads in 5 Critical States as Voters Blast Biden, Times/Siena Poll Finds
description: President Biden is trailing Donald Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 presidential election, according to new polls by The New York Times and Siena College.
content: President Biden is trailing Donald Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 presidential election, according to new polls by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su and Adam Westbrook
title: The Two-State Platitude
description: Once a hope for the future of Israel and Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
content: Once a hope for the future of Israel and Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Associated Press
title: More Than 100,000 March in France Against Antisemitism
description: The demonstrations, called by the leaders of both chambers of the French Parliament, came amid a rise in tensions over the Israel-Gaza War and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
content: The demonstrations, called by the leaders of both chambers of the French Parliament, came amid a rise in tensions over the Israel-Gaza War and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
source.name: The New York Times
